title: Border Crossing Entry Data
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(ggthemes)
library(scales)
library(plotly)


show <- read_csv("01-unclean/Border_Crossing_Entry_Data.csv")

── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (7): Port Name, State, Port Code, Border, Date, Measure, Point
dbl (3): Value, Latitude, Longitude

ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

show


  




border <- read_csv("01-unclean/Border_Crossing_Entry_Data.csv") |>
  clean_names() |>
  mutate(
    border_year = my(date),
    year = year(border_year)
  ) |>
  select(state, border, year, measure, value)

dbl (3): Value, Latitude, Longitude

title: Border Crossing Entry Data
text:
Analysis and Visuals

Numbers by State

clean_border <- read_rds("02-clean/border.rds")


clean_border |>
  count(year)


  




border_state <- clean_border |>
  filter(
    year == 2024
  ) |>
  group_by(state, year) |>
  summarize(
    border_traffic = sum(value)
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(border_traffic))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'state'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

border_state


  




ggplot(
  border_state,
  aes(x = reorder(state, border_traffic), 
      y = border_traffic,
      fill = state
  )
) +
  geom_col(
    aes(),
    show.legend = FALSE
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = label_comma()) +
  labs(
    title = "Amount of Border Traffic per Border State in 2024",
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: Department of Transportation",
    x = "State",
    y = "Border Traffic",
    fill = "State"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








Analysis:
Texas has by far the most border traffic of any other border state with over 120 million crossings in 2024. Although California is closer behind, there is a steep decrease in border traffic around the Canadian border and other Southern states beyond Texas and California.


Country Border Traffic

border_country <- clean_border |>
  group_by(border, year) |>
  summarize(
    border_country_traffic = sum(value)
  ) |>
  arrange(year, border_country_traffic)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'border'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

border_country


  




ggplot(
  border_country,
  aes(
    x = year,
    y = border_country_traffic,
    color = border
  )
) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = label_comma(),
    limits = c(0, 400000000)
  ) +
  geom_line(
    aes(),
    size = 2
  ) +
  labs(
    title = str_wrap("Border Traffic at the Canadian and Mexican borders from 1996 until 2024"),
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: Department of Transportation",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Border Traffic",
    color = "Border"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.









Analysis:
Border traffic along the US-Mexico border almost doubled traffic along the US-Canada border. There was a peak for border traffic along the US-Mexico border around and just before 2000, and a dramatic fall in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic.


Transportation Across the Border(s)

border_transportation <- clean_border |>
  group_by(measure, year) |>
  summarize(
    transportation_numbers = sum(value)
  ) |>
  arrange(year, transportation_numbers)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'measure'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

border_transportation


  




transportation_graph <- ggplot(
  border_transportation,
  aes(
    x = year,
    y = transportation_numbers,
    color = measure
  )
) +
  scale_y_log10(
    breaks = c(100000, 1000000, 10000000, 100000000),
    labels = scales::label_number(accuracy = 1),
  ) +
  geom_line(
    aes(),
    size = 1
  ) +
  labs(
    title = str_wrap("Type of Transportation for Border Traffic from 1996 to 2024"),
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: Department of Transportation",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Border Traffic Transportation Amount",
    color = "Mode of Transportation"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

transportation_graph







ggplotly(transportation_graph)





Analysis:
The vast majority of border traffic is personal vehicle traffic. Pedestrian border traffic blew me away with almost 50 million pedestrians crossing the border in 2019. Group transportation took a hit during the pandemic, with buses dropping more than half of their report in 2019, from almost 230,000 to almost 100,000 in 2020.

title: Crime in Los Angeles
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(ggthemes)
library(scales)
library(plotly)


raw_data <- read_csv("01-unclean/Los-Angeles_Crime.csv") |>
  clean_names()

Warning: One or more parsing issues, call `problems()` on your data frame for details,
e.g.:
  dat <- vroom(...)
  problems(dat)


Rows: 1004847 Columns: 28
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (16): Date Rptd, DATE OCC, TIME OCC, AREA, AREA NAME, Rpt Dist No, Crm C...
dbl (11): DR_NO, Part 1-2, Crm Cd, Vict Age, Premis Cd, Weapon Used Cd, Crm ...
lgl  (1): Crm Cd 4

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

la_crime <- raw_data |>
  mutate(
    date_reported = mdy_hms(date_rptd), 
    date_occurred = mdy_hms(date_occ),
    crime_description = crm_cd_desc,
    year_occurred = year(date_occurred)
  ) |>
  select(
    date_reported,
    date_occurred,
    year_occurred,
    crime_description,
    premis_desc
  )

title: Crime in Los Angeles
text:
Analysis and Visualization

crime_year <- la_crime |>
  mutate(
    crime_description = str_wrap(
      crime_description, width = 20
    )
  ) |>
  group_by(
    year_occurred,
    crime_description
  ) |>
  summarize(
    incident_count = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) |>
  group_by(
    year_occurred
  ) |>
  slice_max(
    incident_count,
    n = 10,
    with_ties = FALSE
  )

crime_year


  




top10_plot <- ggplot(
  crime_year,
  aes(
    x = year_occurred,
    y = incident_count,
    color = crime_description
  )
) +
  geom_point(
    show.legend = FALSE,
    size = 2.2
  ) +
  geom_line(
    linewidth = 1.5
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Crimes in Los Angeles from 2020 to 2024",
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: City of Los Angeles",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of Incidents",
    color = "Type of Crime"
  )
  theme_minimal()

top10_plot







ggplotly(top10_plot)





Analysis:
The most frequent crimes in Los Angeles are non-violent, with an exception of assault and battery. As of 2024, crime in Los Angeles, on all fronts, is declining. Interestingly, in 2022, identity theft was the second most frequent crime, with over 22,000 occurrences. Stolen vehicles have remained at the top of the list over all four years, and it saw a slight peak of almost 25,000 occurrences, also in 2022.

top10_bar <- ggplot(
  crime_year,
  aes(
    x = crime_description,
    y = incident_count,
    fill = crime_description
  )
) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(
    title = "Top 10 Crimes in Los Angeles from 2020 to 2024",
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: City of Los Angeles",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of Incidents",
    fill = "Type of Crime"
  ) +
  facet_wrap(
    ~year_occurred
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.text.x = element_blank()
  )

top10_bar







ggplotly(top10_bar)

title: About
text:
Assignment #1:

Analyze three different (simple) datasets in RStudio

Provide Quarto sites/code for each dataset to review
Create a graphic using ggplot, plotly or Datawrapper for each set (each must be a different visual style — line, bar, map etc.)

For one of the previous sets, create three graphics from the same data (each a different visual style)



Analyses
I analyzed three different datasets from https://data.gov/.

Border Crossing Entry Data, Analysis


Texas has by far the most border traffic of any other border state with over 120 million crossings in 2024. Although California is closer behind, there is a steep decrease in border traffic around the Canadian border and other Southern states beyond Texas and California.
Border traffic along the US-Mexico border almost doubled traffic along the US-Canada border. There was a peak for border traffic along the US-Mexico border around and just before 2000, and a dramatic fall in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic.
The vast majority of border traffic is personal vehicle traffic. Pedestrian border traffic blew me away with almost 50 million pedestrians crossing the border in 2019. Group transportation took a hit during the pandemic, with buses dropping more than half of their report in 2019, from almost 230,000 to almost 100,000 in 2020.


Most Popular Baby Names in New York City, Analysis


Esther and Isabella fought from 2018 to 2020 for the title of most popular, and Esther was, in 2021, the most popular baby name in New York City. This being said, the amount of people naming their female babies the most popular name was on a steep decline over the ten year period.
On a different note, regarding male baby names, it seems to be more popular to name babies the most popular name of the year. This is a strong comparison from almost 450 babies named Liam in 2021 and under 200 named Esther.


Crime in Los Angeles, Analysis


The most frequent crimes in Los Angeles are non-violent, with an exception of assault and battery. As of 2024, crime in Los Angeles, on all fronts, is declining. Interestingly, in 2022, identity theft was the second most frequent crime, with over 22,000 occurrences. Stolen vehicles have remained at the top of the list over all four years, and it saw a slight peak of almost 25,000 occurrences, also in 2022.

title: Most Popular Baby Names in New York City
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(stringr)




baby_names <- read_csv("01-unclean/Popular_Baby_Names.csv") |>
  clean_names() |>
  distinct()

Rows: 69214 Columns: 6
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (3): Gender, Ethnicity, Child's First Name
dbl (3): Year of Birth, Count, Rank

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

baby_names


  







popular <- baby_names |>
  select(
    year_of_birth,
    gender,
    childs_first_name,
    count,
    ethnicity
  ) |>
  mutate(
    childs_first_name = str_to_upper(childs_first_name) |>
      str_trim()
  ) |>
  group_by(
    year_of_birth,
    gender
    # gender, name, and sum of ethnicity count for different babies -- will get you most popular accumulated name rather than separated by race
  ) |>
  slice_max(
    count,
    n = 1,
    with_ties = FALSE
  ) |>
  ungroup() |>
  arrange(year_of_birth, gender)

popular


  




popular_girl <- popular |>
  filter(
    gender == "FEMALE"
  )

popular_girl


  




popular_boy <- popular |>
  filter(
    gender == "MALE"
  )

popular_boy


  




ggplot(
  popular_girl,
  aes(
      x = year_of_birth,
      y = count,
      color = childs_first_name
    )
) +
  geom_point(
    size = 4
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      "ESTHER" = "darkgoldenrod1",
      "ISABELLA" = "darkorchid2"
    )
  ) +
  labs(
    title = str_wrap("Most Popular Female Baby Names in New York City Between 2011 and 2021"),
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: City of New York",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of Babies",
    color = "Child's First Name"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








Analysis:
Esther and Isabella fought from 2018 to 2020 for the title of most popular, and Esther was, in 2021, the most popular baby name in New York City. This being said, the amount of people naming their female babies the most popular name was on a steep decline over the ten year period.

# add zero
#| label: popular boy graph

ggplot(
  popular_boy,
  aes(
      x = year_of_birth,
      y = count,
      color = childs_first_name
    )
) +
  geom_point(
    aes(),
    size = 4
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      "LIAM" = "coral1",
      "JAYDEN" = "cornflowerblue"
    )
  ) +
  labs(
    title = str_wrap("Most Popular Male Baby Names in the New York City Between 2011 and 2021"),
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: City of New York",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of Babies",
    color = "Child's First Name"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








Analysis:
On a different note, regarding male baby names, it seems to be more popular to name babies the most popular name of the year. This is a strong comparison from almost 450 babies named Liam in 2021 and under 200 named Esther.
crumbs: Most Popular Baby Names in New York City

title: Most Popular Baby Names in New York City
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(stringr)




baby_names <- read_csv("01-unclean/Popular_Baby_Names.csv") |>
  clean_names() |>
  distinct()

Rows: 69214 Columns: 6
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr (3): Gender, Ethnicity, Child's First Name
dbl (3): Year of Birth, Count, Rank

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

baby_names


  







popular <- baby_names |>
  select(
    year_of_birth,
    gender,
    childs_first_name,
    count,
    ethnicity
  ) |>
  mutate(
    childs_first_name = str_to_upper(childs_first_name) |>
      str_trim()
  ) |>
  group_by(
    year_of_birth,
    gender
    # gender, name, and sum of ethnicity count for different babies -- will get you most popular accumulated name rather than separated by race
  ) |>
  slice_max(
    count,
    n = 1,
    with_ties = FALSE
  ) |>
  ungroup() |>
  arrange(year_of_birth, gender)

popular


  




popular_girl <- popular |>
  filter(
    gender == "FEMALE"
  )

popular_girl


  




popular_boy <- popular |>
  filter(
    gender == "MALE"
  )

popular_boy


  




ggplot(
  popular_girl,
  aes(
      x = year_of_birth,
      y = count,
      color = childs_first_name
    )
) +
  geom_point(
    size = 4
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      "ESTHER" = "darkgoldenrod1",
      "ISABELLA" = "darkorchid2"
    )
  ) +
  labs(
    title = str_wrap("Most Popular Female Baby Names in New York City Between 2011 and 2021"),
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: City of New York",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of Babies",
    color = "Child's First Name"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








Analysis:
Esther and Isabella fought from 2018 to 2020 for the title of most popular, and Esther was, in 2021, the most popular baby name in New York City. This being said, the amount of people naming their female babies the most popular name was on a steep decline over the ten year period.

# add zero
#| label: popular boy graph

ggplot(
  popular_boy,
  aes(
      x = year_of_birth,
      y = count,
      color = childs_first_name
    )
) +
  geom_point(
    aes(),
    size = 4
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      "LIAM" = "coral1",
      "JAYDEN" = "cornflowerblue"
    )
  ) +
  labs(
    title = str_wrap("Most Popular Male Baby Names in the New York City Between 2011 and 2021"),
    subtitle = str_wrap("Chart created by Meredith Roberts for the Data Visualization Independent Study."),
    caption = "Source: City of New York",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Number of Babies",
    color = "Child's First Name"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()








Analysis:
On a different note, regarding male baby names, it seems to be more popular to name babies the most popular name of the year. This is a strong comparison from almost 450 babies named Liam in 2021 and under 200 named Esther.
